abstracts.cdata!:
The Irrigation and Drainage Sector
            Project's outcome is considered highly satisfactory.
            The main lessons learned are: 1) The ability of governments
            to provide the required funding for the irrigation sector
            from the public budget results in a situation where public
            infrastructure cannot be maintained and is unsustainable
            over time. Strong political will is required to charge the
            full organization and management cost to users of irrigation
            facilities, while devising acceptable transfer mechanisms.
            2) It is important to mitigate the traditional bias that
            government irrigation agencies have in favor of
            infrastructure development as they tend to overlook or
            ignore broader sector policies. 3) The Bank committed itself
            to high standards to assist Mexico with the best efforts
            from preparation to implementation, by assigning top
            expertise, adequate resources, intensive supervision, and
            proactive dialogue. 4) It is important to coordinate with
            Inter-American Development Bank. 5) The creation of
            institutional capacity for project implementation was
            fundamental. 6) The best structure of water fees would be
            through a two-step structure that would consider the volume
            and the irrigation right in the registry. 7) Water user
            organizations were much more efficient than a specialized
            government agency in managing and performing rehabilitation,
            organization & management, and modernization of
            irrigation systems.
